-C.value: try { Use-Icinga; } catch { Write-Output 'The Icinga PowerShell Framework is either not installed on the system or not configured properly. Please check https://icinga.com/docs/windows for further details'; exit 3; }; Exit-IcingaPluginNotInstalled 'Invoke-IcingaCheckCertificate'; exit Invoke-IcingaCheckCertificate

7.description: Used to specify an array of Thumbprints, which are used to determine what certificate to check, within the CertStore.
7.caption: CertThumbprint

9.description: Used to specify which path within the CertStore should be checked.
9.caption: CertStorePath

10.description: Used to specify an array of paths on your system, where certificate files are. Use with CertName.
10.caption: CertPaths

3.description:
Used to specify a date. The start date of the certificate has to be past the date specified, otherwise the check results in critical. Use carefully.
Use format like: 'yyyy-MM-dd'
3.caption: CriticalStart

11.description: Used to specify an array of certificate names of certificate files to check. Use with CertPaths.
11.caption: CertName

2.description:
Used to switch on trusted behavior. Whether to check, If the certificate is trusted by the system root.
Will return Critical in case of untrust.

Note: it is currently required that the root and intermediate CA is known and trusted by the local system.
2.caption: Trusted

4.description:
Used to specify a Warning range for the end date of an certificate. In this case a string.
Allowed units include: ms, s, m, h, d, w, M, y
4.caption: WarningEnd

6.description: Used to specify which CertStore to check. Valid choices are '*', 'LocalMachine', 'CurrentUser'
6.caption: CertStore

5.description:
Used to specify a Critical range for the end date of an certificate. In this case a string.
Allowed units include: ms, s, m, h, d, w, M, y
5.caption: CriticalEnd

8.description: Used to specify an array of Subjects, which are used to determine what certificate to check, within the CertStore.
8.caption: CertSubject
